_documentation: This subcomponent implements systems and processes that develop the knowledge, skills, and infrastructure necessary for diverse communities to effectively participate in democratic alignment of AI systems, ensuring that democratic control of AI is accessible to all affected stakeholders.
name: Deliberative Capacity Building
description: Systems and processes that develop the knowledge, skills, and infrastructure necessary for diverse communities to effectively participate in democratic alignment of AI systems, ensuring that democratic control of AI is accessible to all affected stakeholders.

capabilities.name: AI Literacy Development
capabilities.description: Development of AI literacy for diverse stakeholders across knowledge levels

functions.name: Knowledge Building
functions.description: Build knowledge and understanding of AI systems among diverse stakeholders

specifications.name: Educational Curriculum Specifications
specifications.description: Technical specifications for AI literacy curriculum development and implementation
requirements: Modular learning materials for different knowledge levels
Multilingual and accessible content formats
Interactive learning components for complex AI concepts
Assessment mechanisms to evaluate knowledge acquisition

integration.name: Educational Curriculum Implementation
integration.description: Integration approach for implementing AI literacy programs

techniques.name: Adaptive Learning Frameworks
techniques.description: Techniques for creating adaptable learning frameworks for diverse stakeholders

applications.name: Adaptive AI Literacy Platform
applications.description: Online platform that provides customized AI literacy education based on stakeholder background and needs

inputs.name: Learner Profile
inputs.description: Information about the learner's background, expertise, and learning goals
inputs.constraints: Must include knowledge level, learning preferences, and areas of interest

inputs.name: Content Modules
inputs.description: Library of educational modules on AI topics
inputs.constraints: Must cover technical, ethical, and governance aspects of AI

outputs.name: Personalized Learning Path
outputs.description: Customized sequence of educational materials
outputs.interpretation: Provides structured knowledge acquisition path tailored to learner

outputs.name: Progress Assessment
outputs.description: Evaluation of learner's progress and comprehension
outputs.interpretation: Measures effectiveness of knowledge building and identifies areas for improvement

functions.name: Skill Development
functions.description: Develop technical and conceptual skills needed for understanding AI systems

requirements: Hands-on workshops and practical exercises

Domain-specific practical applications
Collaborative problem-solving approaches

integration.name: Skills Development Implementation
integration.description: Integration approach for implementing AI skill development programs

techniques.name: Workshop-based Skill Building
techniques.description: Techniques for developing practical AI skills through interactive workshops

applications.name: Community AI Skill Workshops
applications.description: Local workshops that build practical AI literacy skills in community settings

inputs.name: Community Needs Assessment
inputs.description: Assessment of the community's specific needs and interests related to AI
inputs.constraints: Must identify skill gaps and practical applications relevant to the community

inputs.name: Workshop Curriculum
inputs.description: Structured curriculum for skill development workshops
inputs.constraints: Must include hands-on exercises and real-world applications

outputs.name: Practical Skills Acquisition
outputs.description: Measurable increase in practical AI skills among participants
outputs.interpretation: Demonstrates improved ability to engage with and evaluate AI systems

outputs.name: Community Project Outcomes
outputs.description: Collaborative projects applying newly acquired skills to community issues
outputs.interpretation: Shows practical application of skills in addressing real community needs

techniques.name: Case-based Learning Technique

overview._documentation: This section provides a concise overview of the deliberative capacity building subcomponent, its purpose, capabilities, and functions for enabling democratic participation in AI alignment.
overview.purpose: To develop and sustain the cognitive, social, and technical capacities required for meaningful democratic participation in AI alignment processes, enabling diverse communities to effectively participate in alignment governance.

key_capabilities.name: AI Literacy Development
key_capabilities.description: Development of AI literacy for diverse stakeholders across knowledge levels

key_capabilities.name: Education Techniques
key_capabilities.description: Specialized techniques for educating stakeholders about AI systems and governance

key_capabilities.name: Participatory Methods
key_capabilities.description: Methods enabling diverse participation in AI governance deliberation

key_capabilities.name: Deliberative Infrastructure
key_capabilities.description: Creation and maintenance of infrastructure for democratic participation

key_capabilities.name: Technical Capacity Building
key_capabilities.description: Building technical capacity for effective participation in AI governance

key_capabilities.name: Knowledge Translation
key_capabilities.description: Translation of knowledge across expertise levels and domains

key_capabilities.name: Inclusive Deliberation Methodologies
key_capabilities.description: Development of methodologies and tools for inclusive deliberation

primary_functions.name: Educational Support
primary_functions.description: Provide educational resources to enhance democratic participation in AI alignment

primary_functions.name: Democratic Expertise Development
primary_functions.description: Develop democratic expertise in AI governance and alignment

primary_functions.name: Democratic Capacity Development
primary_functions.description: Build capacity for democratic deliberation on complex AI alignment issues

primary_functions.name: Knowledge Building
primary_functions.description: Build knowledge and understanding of AI systems among diverse stakeholders

primary_functions.name: Participation Enhancement
primary_functions.description: Enhance stakeholders' ability to effectively participate in AI governance processes

primary_functions.name: Deliberative Skill Development
primary_functions.description: Develop deliberative skills for complex alignment discussions

primary_functions.name: Infrastructure Development
primary_functions.description: Create and maintain technical infrastructure for democratic participation

primary_functions.name: Facilitation Support
primary_functions.description: Build facilitation capacity for inclusive deliberative processes

primary_functions.name: Adaptive Learning
primary_functions.description: Support ongoing learning and adaptation of democratic alignment processes

implementation._documentation: This section details the techniques and their applications used to implement deliberative capacity building for democratic AI alignment.

techniques.name: AI Literacy Development
techniques.description: Approaches for building understanding of AI technologies and implications among diverse stakeholders

applications.name: AI Education Programs
applications.description: Structured programs designed to build AI literacy across knowledge levels
examples: Tiered AI literacy programs for different expertise levels
Community-based AI education with local context integration
Multi-language AI literacy materials with cultural adaptation

applications.name: Technical Concept Translation
applications.description: Translation of complex AI concepts into accessible language and frameworks
examples: Visual explanations of neural network operations
Metaphor-based explanations of machine learning concepts
Multilevel explanations from simplified to detailed technical descriptions

applications.name: Deliberative Skill Training
applications.description: Training programs for developing skills needed in AI governance deliberation
examples: Critical thinking workshops focused on AI ethical reasoning
Structured dialogues on complex AI governance scenarios
Role-playing exercises for multi-stakeholder AI deliberation

techniques.name: Knowledge Translation Methods
techniques.description: Methods for translating knowledge across domains, cultures, and expertise levels to enable inclusive participation

applications.name: Technical to Public Translation
applications.description: Translation of technical AI concepts for public understanding
examples: Technical concept translation using everyday analogies
Visual storytelling of complex AI processes
Interactive demonstrations of AI concepts for non-experts

applications.name: Community Knowledge Integration
applications.description: Methods for integrating community knowledge into technical understanding
examples: Community-expert collaborative knowledge mapping
Two-way knowledge exchange between technical and community experts
Integration of traditional knowledge with AI governance concepts

applications.name: Cross-domain Translation
applications.description: Translation of AI governance concepts across disciplinary domains
examples: Translation frameworks between technical and legal AI governance concepts
Cross-disciplinary glossaries and concept maps
Domain-specific explanations of common AI governance challenges

techniques.name: Deliberative Infrastructure Building
techniques.description: Creation and maintenance of technical, social, and institutional infrastructure for deliberative participation

applications.name: Deliberation Platforms
applications.description: Digital and physical platforms enabling democratic deliberation on AI governance
examples: Multi-access-point digital deliberation platforms
Hybrid online-offline deliberation systems
Accessible deliberation interfaces for diverse stakeholders

applications.name: Accessibility Infrastructure
applications.description: Infrastructure specifically designed to overcome participation barriers
examples: Technology access programs for underserved communities
Multi-format deliberation support for different abilities
Transportation and childcare support for in-person participation

applications.name: Process Documentation Systems
applications.description: Systems for documenting and sharing deliberative processes and outcomes
examples: Accessible archives of deliberation processes and decisions
Multi-format documentation systems with translation
Structured deliberation records with search and analysis capabilities

techniques.name: Inclusion Methods
techniques.description: Methods specifically designed to ensure inclusion of marginalized and underrepresented groups in AI governance

applications.name: Facilitation Capacity Development
applications.description: Building capacity for inclusive facilitation of AI governance deliberations
examples: Inclusive facilitation training for community facilitators
Power-balancing facilitation techniques for AI governance discussions
Cultural competence development for cross-community facilitation

applications.name: Equity-centered Design
applications.description: Design approaches that center equity in deliberative processes and tools
examples: Participatory design of deliberation processes with marginalized communities
Equity impact assessment frameworks for deliberative methods
Design principles that prioritize historically excluded voices

applications.name: Transformative Participation Approaches
applications.description: Approaches that transform power relations through participation design
examples: Community leadership development in AI governance
Structural approaches to shifting decision authority to affected communities
Knowledge co-creation between technical experts and community experts

techniques.name: Adaptive Capacity Building
techniques.description: Approaches for building capacity that adapts to changing AI technologies and governance needs

applications.name: Continuous Learning Systems
applications.description: Systems supporting ongoing learning about evolving AI technologies and governance
examples: Evolving AI governance curriculum that tracks technological change
Update systems for community knowledge about AI developments
Continuous learning communities focused on AI governance

applications.name: Capacity Assessment Frameworks
applications.description: Frameworks for assessing and developing needed capacities as AI evolves
examples: Adaptive capacity metrics that evolve with technology
Community self-assessment tools for governance readiness
Dynamic capacity gap analysis frameworks

applications.name: Equity-centered Design
applications.description: Design approaches that center equity in deliberative processes and tools
examples: Participatory design of deliberation processes with marginalized communities
Equity impact assessment frameworks for deliberative methods
Design principles that prioritize historically excluded voices

applications.name: Participation Support Systems
applications.description: Systems that support evolving participation needs across communities
examples: Adaptable participation frameworks for diverse communities
Evolving support systems for emerging participation needs
Flexible participation infrastructure that responds to feedback

implementation_considerations.name: Knowledge Accessibility
considerations: Adapting technical knowledge for different levels of expertise
Creating accessible explanations across linguistic and cultural contexts
Addressing barriers to knowledge access for marginalized communities
Balancing simplification with meaningful technical understanding

implementation_considerations.name: Expertise Diversity
considerations: Valuing diverse forms of expertise beyond technical knowledge
Integrating community expertise with technical understanding
Preventing technical expertise from dominating deliberation
Building capacity that respects diverse knowledge systems

implementation_considerations.name: Technical Complexity
considerations: Addressing increasing complexity of AI systems in capacity building
Creating tiered approaches for different levels of technical detail
Focusing on governance-relevant technical knowledge
Providing pathways to deeper technical understanding

implementation_considerations.name: Contextualization Needs
considerations: Contextualizing capacity building for different communities and cultures
Adapting approaches to specific governance contexts
Integrating local knowledge into capacity building
Avoiding one-size-fits-all capacity building approaches

implementation_considerations.name: Two-way Translation
considerations: Ensuring bi-directional knowledge flow between experts and communities
Translating community concerns into technical requirements
Creating shared vocabularies across expertise types
Developing feedback loops between technical and non-technical stakeholders

implementation_considerations.name: Technical Access
considerations: Addressing technical barriers to participation in AI governance
Creating accessible interfaces for diverse stakeholders
Overcoming digital divides across communities
Providing technological support for effective participation

implementation_considerations.name: Institutional Support
considerations: Developing institutional capacity to support inclusive deliberation
Creating governance structures that enable capacity building
Integrating capacity building into organizational processes
Securing resources for sustained capacity development

implementation_considerations.name: Sustainability
considerations: Designing capacity building for long-term sustainability
Developing self-sustaining community capacity
Creating renewable resource streams for capacity maintenance
Building infrastructures that persist beyond initial investment

implementation_considerations.name: Power Imbalances
considerations: Addressing power imbalances in capacity building processes
Preventing capacity building from reinforcing existing inequities
Creating transformative approaches to power in deliberation
Centering marginalized communities in capacity development

implementation_considerations.name: Participation Barriers
considerations: Identifying and addressing barriers to participation
Creating accommodations for diverse participation needs
Removing economic barriers to participation
Addressing time constraints for community participants

implementation_considerations.name: Representation Quality
considerations: Ensuring quality of representation in capacity building
Moving beyond tokenistic inclusion to meaningful participation
Building capacity across diverse demographic groups
Creating appropriate sampling and selection methodologies

implementation_considerations.name: Technological Change
considerations: Adapting capacity building to evolving AI technologies
Developing frameworks that remain relevant through technological change
Creating update mechanisms for knowledge and skills as AI advances
Teaching fundamental concepts that transcend specific implementations

implementation_considerations.name: Evolving Needs
considerations: Adapting capacity building to evolving community and stakeholder needs
Creating feedback systems to identify emerging capacity requirements
Developing flexible approaches that can shift focus as needed
Building self-assessment capabilities into capacity development

implementation_considerations.name: Sustained Engagement
considerations: Maintaining stakeholder engagement over long timeframes
Preventing participation fatigue through appropriate design
Creating intrinsically motivating participation experiences
Developing community ownership of ongoing governance processes

technical_specifications._documentation: This section provides technical details about the deliberative capacity building subcomponent, including inputs, outputs, and performance characteristics.

input_requirements.name: Community Capacity Needs
input_requirements.description: Identified capacity needs of communities for AI governance participation
input_requirements.format: Needs assessments, capability analyses, participation barriers
input_requirements.constraints: Must reflect diverse community perspectives and needs

input_requirements.name: Access Needs
input_requirements.description: Specific access requirements for diverse participation
input_requirements.format: Accessibility assessments, accommodation requirements, barrier analyses
input_requirements.constraints: Must address diverse physical, cognitive, and technological needs

input_requirements.name: Learning Needs
input_requirements.description: Identified educational and learning requirements for AI governance participation
input_requirements.format: Learning assessments, knowledge gap analyses, learning style evaluations
input_requirements.constraints: Must account for diverse learning styles and backgrounds

input_requirements.name: Deliberation Requirements
input_requirements.description: Specific requirements for effective deliberation processes
input_requirements.format: Process specifications, deliberation design parameters, procedural needs
input_requirements.constraints: Must support inclusive and effective deliberative processes

input_requirements.name: Local Knowledge
input_requirements.description: Community-specific knowledge relevant to AI governance
input_requirements.format: Local expertise, contextual knowledge, community wisdom
input_requirements.constraints: Must be respected and integrated with technical knowledge

input_requirements.name: Knowledge Gaps
input_requirements.description: Identified gaps in knowledge needed for effective participation
input_requirements.format: Gap analyses, knowledge assessments, literacy evaluations
input_requirements.constraints: Must identify both technical and contextual knowledge needs

input_requirements.name: AI Governance Requirements
input_requirements.description: Knowledge and capability requirements for effective AI governance
input_requirements.format: Capability frameworks, knowledge maps, skill taxonomies
input_requirements.constraints: Must be relevant to democratic participation needs

input_requirements.name: Facilitation Challenges
input_requirements.description: Identified challenges in facilitating inclusive AI governance deliberations
input_requirements.format: Challenge assessments, facilitation barrier analyses, process difficulties
input_requirements.constraints: Must address power dynamics and participation barriers

input_requirements.name: Capacity Gaps
input_requirements.description: Identified gaps in community capacity for AI governance participation
input_requirements.format: Capacity assessment reports, gap analyses, needs evaluations
input_requirements.constraints: Must consider diverse dimensions of capacity across communities

input_requirements.name: Stakeholder Needs
input_requirements.description: Needs of diverse stakeholders in AI governance processes
input_requirements.format: Stakeholder needs assessments, participation requirements, support needs
input_requirements.constraints: Must reflect diverse stakeholder groups and their contexts

input_requirements.name: Skill Gaps
input_requirements.description: Identified gaps in skills needed for effective AI governance participation
input_requirements.format: Skill assessments, capability gaps, development needs
input_requirements.constraints: Must address both technical and deliberative skills

input_requirements.name: Design Requirements
input_requirements.description: Requirements for designing inclusive participation processes and tools
input_requirements.format: Design specifications, user requirements, accessibility standards
input_requirements.constraints: Must center equity and inclusion in design approach

input_requirements.name: Technical AI Knowledge
input_requirements.description: Technical information about AI systems requiring translation
input_requirements.format: Technical documentation, system specifications, algorithm descriptions
input_requirements.constraints: Must include relevant technical details for meaningful participation

input_requirements.name: Cultural Context Information
input_requirements.description: Information about cultural contexts for capacity adaptation
input_requirements.format: Cultural context analyses, community input, adaptation requirements
input_requirements.constraints: Must reflect diverse cultural perspectives and knowledge systems

input_requirements.name: Audience Profiles
input_requirements.description: Profiles of target audiences for capacity building initiatives
input_requirements.format: Demographic data, knowledge baselines, cultural contexts
input_requirements.constraints: Must reflect diverse stakeholder groups accurately

input_requirements.name: Deliberation Processes
input_requirements.description: Existing and planned deliberation processes requiring documentation
input_requirements.format: Process descriptions, procedural frameworks, participation structures
input_requirements.constraints: Must capture both formal and informal aspects of deliberation

input_requirements.name: Transformation Goals
input_requirements.description: Goals for transforming power relations in AI governance
input_requirements.format: Transformation frameworks, equity goals, power-shifting objectives
input_requirements.constraints: Must address structural power imbalances

input_requirements.name: Evolving Requirements
input_requirements.description: Changing requirements for capacity as AI governance evolves
input_requirements.format: Trend analyses, future scenarios, emerging capability needs
input_requirements.constraints: Must be forward-looking while remaining practical

input_requirements.name: Power Analyses
input_requirements.description: Analyses of power dynamics in AI governance contexts
input_requirements.format: Power mappings, structural analyses, influence assessments
input_requirements.constraints: Must address both visible and invisible forms of power

input_requirements.name: Technology Developments
input_requirements.description: Emerging developments in AI requiring capacity adaptations
input_requirements.format: Technology trend analyses, capability assessments, emerging applications
input_requirements.constraints: Must be accessible to non-technical stakeholders

input_requirements.name: Documentation Needs
input_requirements.description: Requirements for documenting deliberative processes
input_requirements.format: Documentation specifications, transparency requirements, archival needs
input_requirements.constraints: Must support accountability and knowledge sharing

input_requirements.name: Accessibility Barriers
input_requirements.description: Barriers limiting accessibility of AI governance participation
input_requirements.format: Barrier assessments, accessibility audits, participation obstacles
input_requirements.constraints: Must address physical, cognitive, technical, and social barriers

input_requirements.name: Deliberation Challenges
input_requirements.description: Challenges in effective deliberation on AI governance
input_requirements.format: Challenge assessments, deliberation barriers, process difficulties
input_requirements.constraints: Must address cognitive, social, and procedural challenges

input_requirements.name: Cross-discipline Needs
input_requirements.description: Requirements for translation across disciplinary boundaries
input_requirements.format: Interdisciplinary translation needs, domain knowledge gaps, conceptual barriers
input_requirements.constraints: Must address diverse disciplinary perspectives

input_requirements.name: Technical Documentation
input_requirements.description: Technical documentation about AI systems requiring translation
input_requirements.format: Technical specifications, research papers, system architectures
input_requirements.constraints: Must include accurate technical details while being translatable

input_requirements.name: Accommodation Needs
input_requirements.description: Specific accommodations needed for diverse participation
input_requirements.format: Accommodation requirements, support needs, participation enablers
input_requirements.constraints: Must address diverse physical, cognitive, and situational needs

input_requirements.name: Public Knowledge Levels
input_requirements.description: Baseline knowledge levels in public audiences about AI
input_requirements.format: Knowledge assessments, literacy surveys, understanding metrics
input_requirements.constraints: Must address diverse public audiences across demographics

output_specifications.name: Capacity Building Programs

output_specifications.format: Educational programs, skill development frameworks, resources

output_specifications.description: Resources supporting participation in AI governance

output_specifications.usage: Building understanding across diverse knowledge levels

output_specifications.name: Participation Mechanisms
output_specifications.description: Mechanisms enabling diverse participation in AI governance
output_specifications.format: Participation structures, engagement tools, inclusive methodologies

output_specifications.name: Deliberative Spaces
output_specifications.description: Physical and digital spaces for deliberation on AI governance
output_specifications.format: Deliberation platforms, meeting spaces, dialogue environments

output_specifications.name: Knowledge Updates
output_specifications.description: Updated knowledge about evolving AI technologies and governance
output_specifications.format: Knowledge updates, continuing education materials, trend briefings

output_specifications.name: Skill Development Programs
output_specifications.description: Programs for developing skills needed in AI governance
output_specifications.format: Training programs, skill development frameworks, learning pathways
output_specifications.usage: Building necessary skills for effective participation

output_specifications.name: Interdisciplinary Frameworks
output_specifications.description: Frameworks bridging different disciplinary perspectives on AI
output_specifications.format: Cross-domain translations, interdisciplinary models, bridging concepts

output_specifications.name: Participation Tools

output_specifications.format: Digital tools, facilitation aids, engagement technologies

output_specifications.name: Knowledge Resources

output_specifications.format: Educational materials, concept translations, knowledge repositories

performance_characteristics.throughput: Capacity building programs should reach at least 100 participants per community per year
performance_characteristics.latency: Knowledge resources should be updated within 2 weeks of relevant AI advancements
performance_characteristics.scalability: Deliberative infrastructure should scale to support communities of various sizes (10-100,000+)
performance_characteristics.resource_utilization: Programs should operate within resource constraints of target communities

relationships._documentation: This section details how this subcomponent relates to other components and subcomponents in the architecture.

items.description: Deliberative capacity building enables effective participation in value definition processes, while value definition provides requirements for needed capacities
Deliberative capacity building enables effective participation in governance structures, while governance provides contexts for applying deliberative capacities
Deliberative capacity building enables effective participation in verification processes, while verification identifies specific capacity needs

internal_integrations.description: Exchanges capacity requirements and participation support
internal_integrations.data_flow: Participatory value definition identifies capacity needs for effective participation, while capacity building provides knowledge and skills to enable participation

internal_integrations.description: Exchanges governance capacity and participation contexts
internal_integrations.data_flow: Democratic governance provides contexts requiring specific capacities, while capacity building enables effective community participation in governance

internal_integrations.description: Exchanges verification capacity and knowledge needs
internal_integrations.data_flow: Participatory verification identifies knowledge and skill needs for effective verification, while capacity building provides those capabilities to diverse stakeholders

external_integrations.description: Receives explanation frameworks for capacity building
Builds capacity for participation in oversight processes
external_integrations.data_format: Oversight participation frameworks and knowledge requirements

external_integrations.description: Builds capacity for participation in value learning processes
external_integrations.data_format: Value learning participation knowledge and frameworks

external_integrations.description: Translates technical safeguard knowledge for stakeholder understanding
external_integrations.data_format: Accessible explanations of technical safeguard frameworks

literature_connections.relevant_aspects: Provides frameworks for understanding AI alignment concepts that can be adapted for public education, examining how technical AI concepts can be made accessible to broader audiences while maintaining substantive understanding

Offers approaches for translating complex alignment concepts across different knowledge domains, exploring how technical alignment concepts can be communicated effectively to diverse stakeholders with varying levels of technical expertise
Discusses the evolving nature of alignment problems requiring continuous learning and adaptation, examining how alignment challenges evolve with technological progress
Presents constitutional AI frameworks that can be translated for public understanding and engagement, providing concrete models that can be explained to diverse stakeholders
Offers feedback processes that can be adapted for democratic deliberation infrastructure, providing structured feedback mechanisms applicable to deliberative capacity development
Provides frameworks for democratic enhancement of AI through participatory infrastructure, examining how to build infrastructure that enables democratic participation in AI governance
Offers approaches for translating technical AI concepts for democratic participation, exploring how technical knowledge can be made accessible for meaningful democratic participation
Presents participatory design approaches that center equity in AI governance processes, focusing on methods that ensure marginalized communities can effectively participate
Provides frameworks for ensuring diverse stakeholder inclusion in AI oversight, examining how oversight systems can be designed to include diverse perspectives
Outlines infrastructure requirements for effective oversight that can be applied to deliberative capacity building, describing oversight frameworks adaptable to capacity building
Provides a comprehensive survey of alignment approaches that can inform AI literacy programs, offering a knowledge base that can be translated for diverse audiences

Synthesizes complex alignment research in ways that can be used for knowledge translation, organizing technical alignment approaches in a structure that facilitates translation across expertise levels
Examines the evolving landscape of alignment research that requires adaptive capacity building approaches, highlighting how alignment approaches evolve and inform adaptive capacity development
Outlines reward modeling approaches that require ongoing adaptation as systems evolve, discussing how capacity building must adapt to increasingly capable systems
Provides interpretability methods that can make AI systems understandable to diverse stakeholders, offering tools that can be used in capacity building to explain model decisions
Proposes mechanisms for verifiable claims about AI that can be used in deliberative infrastructure, providing infrastructure elements for democratic deliberation
